channel.title: A few software problems
channel.description:
I recently got ubuntu 10.04 LTS Desktop Edition, and it all installed just fine but it won't read my CD's, or my wireless network adapter. Any idea's why?
I tried to install the adapters files, but it would not work. So I seen the 'built in' network adapter, and it did not work either.
I called their support, and they said to call the manufacturer of the wireless network adapter which is Belkin. After an hour of being on the phone with their tech support they finally told me I would have to call the Linux tech support.. I told them I did, and what they said.. But they still insisted that I recall them so I did.. And they both kept redirecting me to call the other company.
I decided to come here and see if any of you know how to fix this? I hate using Windows XP on my desktop.. I am on my laptop atm with Windows 7 which is way better then XP..
So any ideas on what could be wrong, or how to fix it?

item.title: A few software problems
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

It was probably Jockey, it’s included with Ubuntu and can install proprietary drivers they can’t legally ship with the live cd. Great!

Read full topic

item.title: A few software problems
item.dc:creator: @Explisionist Explisionist
item.description:
@Explisionist wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:6, topic:375928”][quote author=Explisionist link=topic=471862.msg3452036#msg3452036 date=1293816914]

Chances are they don’t have drivers for your card yet ^.^ Not built in anyways. This is what totally turned me off about Linux.

Uh, windows NEVER has drivers built in. Linux most of the time comes with every driver you will ever need available.

Run a few commands and paste the results here, run these:
lsusb
lsmod
lspci
(you may or may not have to run them with sudo)

Nothing ):

lsmod popped unrecognized …
[/quote]

Sorry, run them on the command line. So, from the ubuntu docs:

Starting a Terminal
In Gnome (Ubuntu)
The terminal can be found at Applications menu -> Accessories -> Terminal.

In Xfce (Xubuntu)
The terminal can be found at Applications menu -> System -> Terminal.

In KDE (Kubuntu)
The terminal can be found at KMenu -> System -> Terminal Program (Konsole).

In LXDE (Lubuntu)
The terminal can be found at Menu -> Accessories -> LXTerminal.

For general info regarding that: https://help.ubuntu.com/community/UsingTheTerminal

So post the results of those commands now. :)[/quote]
:o What ever I just did made a screen pop up. “Installing driver(s) for Belkin Wireless G Network adapter.” And its loading my network. Thanks Mitb one of those commands or something I clicked made it work. It sucks being a new Linux user lol.

Read full topic

(you may or may not have to run them with sudo)
[/quote]

Sorry, run them on the command line. So, from the ubuntu docs:

Starting a Terminal

The terminal can be found at Applications menu -> System -> Terminal.

In KDE (Kubuntu)

For general info regarding that: https://help.ubuntu.com/community/UsingTheTerminal

So post the results of those commands now.
